cluster_relations.rel_desc: Warm colors encourage or increase impulse purchases.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Color Psychology & Consumer Response in Branding
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Color Psychology & Consumer Response in Branding

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: in purchase contexts where warm colors are used

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Use of color in branding and design influences consumer brand perceptions.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Color in branding and design affects perceptions of a brand's personality.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when consumers view color usage in branding

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Color in branding and design affects perceptions of brand quality.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Color in branding and design affects perceptions of brand value.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A causal or quasi-causal relation where the subject exerts a psychological or behavioral influence on the object, typically in consumer or branding contexts.
args.justification: All relations describe color usage in branding (or warm colors in purchasing contexts) exerting a psychological or behavioral influence on consumer responses (impulse purchases, brand perceptions, behavior, personality, quality, value). They share the same directional, causal-influence semantics, so a unified canonical predicate 'influences' is appropriate.
args.remark: Instance-level qualifiers (e.g., probabilistic, contextual conditions) remain on each relation; the canonical predicate captures the generic influence semantics.

args.justification: Each relation links a branding/color stimulus to a consumer response (perception, evaluation, or behavior). This fits a common class of relations where marketing or design features cause or modulate consumer psychological and behavioral effects.
args.remark: This class can generalize to other marketing stimuli → consumer response influence relations, not limited strictly to color.

args.justification: The relations explicitly describe that the subject (color usage) affects or encourages the object (consumer perceptions or behaviors), with qualifiers indicating causal or probabilistic influence, which belongs under a causal semantics group.

executed_decisions.justification: The relations explicitly describe that the subject (color usage) affects or encourages the object (consumer perceptions or behaviors), with qualifiers indicating causal or probabilistic influence, which belongs under a causal semantics group.
